title: Disclaimer
body: I don’t intend this to be a tutorial on how to solve this challenge.  While it contains some tips I expect you to take into account, and that I judge will be of some help, I don’t intend to step on your toes, so I leave up to you to decide what has to be done in order to complete the challenge.  Although it is written is a step-by-step manner, you don’t need to follow the lines.  I do, however, suggest you go step by step for the sake of guaranteeing you finish all the tasks.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.body:
1. Visual Studio 2010 or later version
  2. NUnit (http://www.nunit.org)
  3. (optional) TestDriven.net Test Runner - you can always use NUnit Test Runner (or any other tool) outside Visual Studio, if you prefer

ReSharper is optional, however, if you use it daily, I strongly recommend you try to use it during the workshop too. You might get to know new things you’ll want to try out later.

items.title: Set up your environment
items.body:
1. Go to https://github.com/alexmiranda/trip-service-kata and clone the project - or download the zip version - to your machine.
  2. Open the project with Visual Studio
  3. Familiarise yourself with the project structure and code
  4. Have a look into the class TripService and try to guess what it does, and what it is for
  5. Now you are able to proceed. Go and add NUnit and Add References to the project TripServiceKata into the test project called TripServiceKata.Test

title: Write your first unit test
body:
What would be your first unit test? And why?
What is hampering you from completing the most simple of unit tests in this scenario?
Remember the instructions given during the workshop about the shortest and deepest branch.
Remember to give each unit test a meaningful name, that reflects its purpose and intention.

title: Get rid of the dependencies in order to get your first unit test green
body:
Are you ready for your first refactoring? I hear you say ‘Yes’, so now remember:

A refactoring is a change in code that does not affect its purpose or intention, thus it should not change the outcome of the System Under Test* (SUT), yet it does add super cool new things, such as readability and testability.

What are the ways you found out to isolate the UserSession dependency from the code at hand? Compare this with what a Mock framework does.
Have your Unit Test Code* changed due to the changes you’ve made in your production code*?

title: Carry on unit testing
body:
Now that you have finally got your first unit test pass, you’ve got to write new unit tests to improve your Test Code Coverage *. You need to keep your unit tests simple enough not to get unmotivated with the task at hand. It’s not that simple, but you’ll soon find out that taking this approach is the safest way to change your code.
Remember the two ways in which people change their code:

  • Write unit test and refactor
  • Change and pray

You have already felt like any change you make causes a new bug, things stopped working and you don’t know why the hell they did, haven’t you? So you won’t like taking the 2nd approach, will you? Say out loud (in your mind): I WANNA WRITE UNIT TESTS FIRST!

Now think of the next unit test you would write. Here goes some tips:

  • It must be the shortest branch you’ve not taken yet
  • If you have a code coverage tool, check out what is not covered yet by running your Unit Tests with the coverage tool. It will help you identify what still needs to be covered.
  • Read through the lines in your production code identifying statements that defines or helps defining the method’s return value, exceptions which are thrown, values which are returned from dependencies, etc.

title: Get your unit test doubles to work dynamically
body:
If you have chosen to use a class which extends from TripService and overrides the definition for GetLoggedInUser, you may want to reuse the same class in different scenarios. That is, instead of repeating the same process on and on, you can avoid creating a huge list of test doubles* by creating one that works like a marionette *.
Think of ways that could be achieved. Try to reach as many solutions as you can and write down the pros and cons of each alternative. It’ll help you choose the solutions that fits better in your scenario. Here goes a list of alternative I expect you to evaluate, but don’t limit yourself to the list:

  • Passing a delegate in the class constructor or setter after instantiation
  • Setting a property containing the expected logged in User, on every unit test
  • Create an interface which will be responsible for providing the logged in user and use polymorphism to pass different implementations each time your need a valid logged in user
  • Get your overridden method to return a mocked out object with proper setup to dynamically return the proper user
  • Any combinations of the options above


Compare your final code with what a Mock framework does for you. What are the differences? Where goes all the setting up, function references (delegates, Action<> and Func<>), callbacks and logic behind a Mock object if you were using a (decent) Mock framework?

title: Clean up the mess
body:
Have you noticed how similar the unit tests you’ve written so far are? Do you think they need some organisation and cleaning up?

What I always say is that unit test code is as important as your production code, inasmuch as you’ll need to visit it again (a thousand times, believe me), maintain it and change it with the same frequency, and it also goes under most of the motivations to be changed as the production code. It is, somehow, even more important when it comes to understanding what your production code does, as it works as a low level documentation for developers. You shall never overlook the power of unit tests :)

Go and extract some fields, add a setup method* to your unit test class. When you think it is enough to stop refactoring the test code, take a look to note how easier they are to read now. Well done!

title: Take time to think of what you’ve accomplished
body:
Hey, you’ve done a pretty good job so far. Be proud of yourself, that is way better the way you used to do it, isn’t it? You should now prepare yourself for the next steps, but there is always room for improvement, right?

Let’s take this moment as an opportunity to understand what is the real value behind unit tests.

You might’ve noticed that, in order to your unit tests do what they need to do, they contain a lot of constants and weirdos such as NULL being passed as parameter arguments and variables being initialised with objects constructed for a sole purpose of fulfilling your unit tests inputs*.

Think now what that really means. You see how passing NULL in place of method parameters are defying you read your tests the way you want? They’re hampering out identifying what the NULL parameter actually is, because without looking further into your code (or inspecting using your IDE facilities), you cannot make sure what the type of the argument it really is.

You need to reveal your intentions. Every programmer who will look at your test code in the future, will get the some troubles to understand what a NULL in the middle of the test code means, because you didn’t make it clear to them.

Think over what would be a variable of type User, whose initial value is NULL, and is expected in place of an method called GetLoggedInUser? Hey, I know that! If you’ve worked professionally as a software developer for a brief time at least, you may have heard people talking about Guest or Anonymous users, referring to them as they were any user who is not identified by the system in a given moment in time. Go ahead and introduce this concept as a constant, make clear for your colleagues who will read your unit tests, really expecting they will help them out.

Repeat the same process for every NULL or object initialisation in your code. Extract their concepts and give them an appropriate name. You see? That’s wonderful.

title: A second dependency shows up!
body:
Now it's time to work on getting rid of UserDAO, which is a second dependency of our TripService class. This is a static class, that for now, we can't really touch, because it's not intended to be tested in the TripServiceTests class.

You might be writing a testing such as ShouldReturnFriendTripsWhenUsersAreFriend. For now, let's apply the same process we did with UserSession. And later we'll come back and give it a try.

f you chose to write an override method that changes the behaviour of TripDAO.FindTripsByUser(user), according to your expectations in a test case, you'll want to write a method that returns the user's trips, being the user the one you passed as a parameter to the GetTripsByUser method. You should avoid to use a mock object, and that's a good example of where you should not use a mock. Instead use a real objects, of class User, as they will not change the behaviour of your tests, nor your production code. The real object will facilitate other developers to familiarise with the API they shall use, including the objects classes they use to interact with your service.

Pay much attention on whether you might be abusing of Mock objects, as in most of the cases, they'll not be needed, therefore they only add unnecessary complexity to your test code. You must think of them as a tool, that is appropriate for a very specific job. Use it with caution.

title: So now what? It's time to refactor
body:
By this point, you might've reached a 100% test code coverage, that's great! Now you can make any change you want to the system under test, and if you introduce any change that breaks the unit tests, you'll know right away that something is wrong and you'll need either solving it or reverting back your goddamn changes. Sounds cool, doesn't it? And it fact it is.

The biggest advantage of this approach when you hit this point, is that now you're on easy street. With all those unit tests in place no change will result in an outrageous change in behaviour, therefore no more maddening bugs being raised on a Friday afternoon, except if they've been already there =)

title: Our first look at a component
body:
This component you're reading is a text component. All components take this form of a title and body - except a blank component. However it's important to realise that title and body attributes are not needed.

Take for instance the media component opposite or below on a smaller device - has no body attribute. Instead of the HTML being rendered Adapt simply doesn't render it. The title attribute is simply a break tag to push the media component level with the opposite component.

title: Key Facts
body: We live in a multi-device world. The growth of internet enabled devices such as smartphones, tablets and laptops means that increasingly we have to deliver learning solutions that work on all devices. This is not as simple as a desktop and mobile solution; what is required is a multi-device solution. Click the + icons below for more.

items.title: Introduction
items.body:
With the advent of modern browsers, frameworks, developments in HTML 5 and responsive design approaches we're now able to create engaging learning that will work, regardless of the device being used.

In addition, Libraries such as Backbone, Underscore and Handlebars have rapidly sped up development and enabled the production of fast single page applications (SPAs) that improve the user experience.

items.title: What is responsive elearning?
items.body:
Responsive elearning Design takes its inspiration from Responsive Web Design; an approach to design that ensures a single version of a website (or an elearning course created as a web app) can provide a viewing experience optimised to complement a variety of different devices, from desktop monitor to smartphone.This tailored viewing experience is achieved by:
  • providing dynamic layouts which allow for the resizing of onscreen elements to make the most of the space available (fluid grid concept)
  • automatically detecting the characteristics of the device being used and applying an appropriate style to all onscreen elements (Media queries and CSS)
  • ensuring all images can be scaled to complement the device being used at the time

title: Scrolling: Some considerations
body: Here are some reasons why we think scrolling is perfectly fine – and even desirable: Select the headings below to reveal the text.

items.title: Your learners already do it
items.body:
Visit a website today and vertical scrolling will most likely factor into the overall design of the site. Users understand what’s expected of them and are scrolling down the page to read content. Feedback from our user trialling of scrolling page designs supports the assertion that users ‘get it’. Actually, they preferred this approach over more traditional template designs.

Surely we want to present learning that uses conventions our audience is most comfortable with?

items.title: Device proof your learning
items.body: More and more learners are accessing content on a wide range of devices and each of these devices will display pages differently. The only thing you can guarantee is if you’re accessing content on a smartphone vertical scrolling will be required. Why not embrace this and place responsive design and vertical scrolling at the heart of your design?

items.title: Meaningful navigation
items.body: It's common sense to cluster any related content on a single page that’s either as short or as long as it needs to be.  Not only does this reduce any unnecessary navigation, it also helps the learner make sense of the structure and the relationship between content. Navigation becomes meaningful, rather than a by-product of the template size.

items.alt: ‘Everything above the fold’ might be old hat but...
items.title: ‘Everything above the fold’ might be old hat but...
items.body: ...The principle remains. Due to the variety of devices used to access web content you’ll only be able to guarantee the first 400 or 500 pixels of a page will be visible, so there’s no harm in putting the important stuff first and hooking your learners early. In fact, we advocate this as good practice, regardless of what page layouts are being used.

items.title: More flexibility
items.body: Scrolling pages still allow you to present content via interactive elements (we call them components instead of templates), but with a scrolling page there is far more flexibility in how these elements are presented. Layouts can now vary in size and the density of content, which in turn creates more space for branding to be incorporated. Or indeed some precious white space to give the content space to breathe.  Overruns are also a thing of the past meaning localisation of content becomes a simpler proposition as well.

items.alt: Don’t throw the baby out with the bath water
items.title: Don’t throw the baby out with the bath water
items.body: None of the above means we stop following instructional design best practice.  We continue to put the learner at the heart of what we produce, writing well-structured which follows an appropriate learning model. It’s more about looking around at what is going on within the wider web community and taking note of changes in best practice and the nature of how content, is being accessed.

title: Key benefits of a vertical scrolling approach
body: Can you identify a few of the benefits that a vertical scrolling approach offers over the traditional back and next approach? Select one or more options from the list below and select Submit.

items.text: Vertical scrolling as a means of navigation on the web is common place and therefore familiar to users
Placing scrolling at the heart of your approach means designs are more mobile friendly
It reduces the need for unnecessary navigation as pages can be as long as they need to be
It means that you no longer need to first gain your learners' attention

feedback.correct:
That’s correct. Your users are almost certainly using vertical scrolling whenever they interact with the web so why reinvent the wheel? Scrolling is also a given when viewing content on a smartphone so any page which is structured with this in mind will help make the design and its navigation feel well thought through for mobile. Clustering related content within a single page should definitely reduce the need to navigate to a different page, as well as that repetitive ‘Click next to continue’ instruction as well.

Of course, we should always try to gain the learners attention early on the page, it’s just that now, when we have it, we aren’t asking them to go somewhere else. The design challenge is now to give them a reason to scroll and venture down ‘below the fold’. To continue close this tutor pop-up.
incorrect:
Sorry, that’s not right. Your users are almost certainly using vertical scrolling whenever they interact with the web so why reinvent the wheel? Scrolling is also a given when viewing content on a smartphone so any page which is structured with this in mind will help make the design and its navigation feel well thought through for mobile. Clustering related content within a single page should definitely reduce the need to navigate to a different page, as well as that repetitive ‘Click next to continue’ instruction as well.

Of course, we should always try to gain the learners attention early on the page, it’s just that now, when we have it, we aren’t asking them to go somewhere else. The design challenge is now to give them a reason to scroll and venture down ‘below the fold’. To continue close this tutor pop-up.

Sorry, that’s not right. Your users are almost certainly using vertical scrolling whenever they interact with the web so why reinvent the wheel? Scrolling is also a given when viewing content on a smartphone so any page which is structured with this in mind will help make the design and its navigation feel well thought through for mobile. Clustering related content within a single page should definitely reduce the need to navigate to a different page, as well as that repetitive ‘Click next to continue’ instruction as well.

Of course, we should always try to gain the learners attention early on the page, it’s just that now, when we have it, we aren’t asking them to go somewhere else. The design challenge is now to give them a reason to scroll and venture down ‘below the fold’. To continue close this tutor pop-up.
feedback.partly:
That’s not quite right. Your users are almost certainly using vertical scrolling whenever they interact with the web so why reinvent the wheel? Scrolling is also a given when viewing content on a smartphone so any page which is structured with this in mind will help make the design and its navigation feel well thought through for mobile. Clustering related content within a single page should definitely reduce the need to navigate to a different page, as well as that repetitive ‘Click next to continue’ instruction as well.

Of course, we should always try to gain the learners attention early on the page, it’s just that now, when we have it, we aren’t asking them to go somewhere else. The design challenge is now to give them a reason to scroll and venture down ‘below the fold’. To continue close this tutor pop-up.

title: What’s coming next?
body: Find out what’s on the roadmap for 2014 for Adapt Learning.

items.title: Improvements
items.body: Over the next few months we’ll be working on a number of developments to improve Adapt Learning to ensure it’s the leading elearning framework for responsive content. At the heart of these developments are two key pieces of work.

items.title: 1: Plug-in Friendly Architecture
items.body: We’re in the process of reworking the codebase to ensure a plugin friendly approach. This will help us to establish an extensive and vibrant open source community to support the framework and adhere to the principles of collaborative development.

items.title: 2: Authoring Tool
items.body: We’re also creating an authoring tool to allow non-technical users to create fully featured Adapt elearning courses. The authoring tool will be simple enough for novices to use yet powerful enough to meet the needs of the elearning professional.

title: Getting involved
body: How can anyone get involved with Adapt? Select the correct answers below.

items.text: Sign up to the community site

feedback.correct: That's correct. There are multiple ways of getting involved with Adapt. However signing up to the community site is the best way to see discussions, news and feature requests.
feedback.partly: Not quite correct. Actually it's all three answers - There are multiple ways of getting involved with Adapt. However signing up to the community site is the best way to see discussions, news and feature requests.
feedback.incorrect: That's not correct. All three answers are correct - There are multiple ways of getting involved with Adapt. However signing up to the community site is the best way to see discussions, news and feature requests.

title: Order of a page
body: Put in order, the elements as they are viewed in a standard Adapt page

feedback.correct: That's correct. Think A, B, C when creating Adapt courses.
feedback.incorrect: FINAL This feedback will appear if you answered the question incorrectly.
feedback.partly: FINAL and NON-FINAL This feedback will appear if you answered part of the question correctly.

title: Extensions
body: Name the two extensions being used on this page?

feedback.correct: This feedback will appear if you answered the question correctly.
feedback.incorrect: This feedback will appear if you answered the question incorrectly.

title: Matching
body: Basically what you need to do is match the questions below with the drop down box option.

feedback.correct: FINAL and NON-FINAL This feedback will appear if you answered the question correctly.
incorrect: FINAL This feedback will appear if you answered the question incorrectly.
NON-FINAL This feedback will appear if you answered the question incorrectly.
feedback.partly: FINAL and NON-FINAL This feedback will appear if you answered part of the question correctly.

title: Content is king
body:
The internet has proven to be a content based technology with more than 50% of a users time being spent online reading content, with an additional 30% of their time on social media networks.

So sometimes a simple text component does the job.

title: Imagery helps to tell a story
body: For content that needs a visual effect we have a graphic component. To optimise this for various devices, this  component swaps out images based upon your screen size. Giving the user the best experience possible according to their device's spec.

title: Headlines to grab attention
body: The accordion component enables a content creator to pick some catchy titles that reveal more information. Select the headings below to reveal the text.

items.title: Missing title and body elements
items.body: As mentioned before, title and body elements on components are not compulsory. The same is true for articles and blocks.

items.title: Use space
items.body: One important learning pattern to remember is to not fill every component. This can lead to a poor user experience on smaller screens. We're use to scrolling on smaller devices so use up the vertical space.

items.alt: Think about background images for decoration
items.title: Think about background images for decoration
items.body: One way of bringing content to life is adding background images to blocks or articles. We suggest doing this after the content is produced so the imagery can aid the learning.

title: Narrative
body: This is optional body text. Select the forward arrows to move through the narrative on a desktop, or swipe the images and select the plus icons to do so on mobile.

items.title: Tell a story
items.body: Narratives should be used to tell a story or to help learners with a process that needs to be in order.

items.title: Optimised for touch events
items.body: The narrative was built with touch devices in mind - so you can swipe through the images if you device is touch enabled.

items.title: How a narrative looks on mobile
items.body: If viewing on desktop or tablet, this text will appear to the right of the image. On mobile, you’ll need to select the plus icon to reveal this text.
items.strapline: How a narrative looks on mobile

title: Hot graphic
body: The hot graphic component enables the learner to interact with an image by clicking on the hot spots to reveal more. This component will scale down to a narrative when viewed on mobile. Select the hotspots on the image to reveal the text.

items.title: Single components
items.body: Single components are interactions that enable two components in a block. These take up half of a blocks width.

items.title: Spanned components
items.body: Spanned components are interactions that take up a full block and do not allow another component to sit next to it.

items.title: Single and Spanned components
items.body: Some components are both single and spanned. This means they can sit with another component or fill a whole block. Some exmaples are: Graphic, Text and Media

title: Media component
body: As mentioned above in the hot graphic - a media component is both a single and spanned component. Below is a media component spanned.

title: MCQ
body: A multiple choice question items each have a text attribute and whether the item is correct. An MCQ can also set the items to display in a random order and allow multiple items to be selected. What does MCQ standard for? Select an item below and click submit.

feedback.correct: Congratulations, this is the correct answer.
feedback.partly: Not quite right, this is partly correct.
feedback.incorrect: Unfortunately this is the incorrect answer.

title: Matching
body: A matching component allows multiple question stems that each have their own individual drop down. All feedback for questions are passed out through an event system so extensions can display feedback how they want. Core comes bundled with a plugin called Tutor. Match the questions below with the drop down box option.

feedback.correct: This feedback will appear if you answered the question correctly.
feedback.incorrect: This feedback will appear if you answered the question incorrectly.
feedback.partly: This feedback will appear if you answered part of the question correctly.

items.text: What is the core bundled feedback extension called?
Can I build another extension to show feedback?

title: Text input
body: Text input allows the learner to input a text field into one of the items. This component can check whether you need items to be case sensitive, allow punctuation and allow items to be inserted in any order. Name one type of plugin Adapt supports?

feedback.correct: That's correct. Adapt allows the following plugins: A theme, components, extensions and a menu
feedback.incorrect: That's not correct. Adapt allows the following plugins: A theme, components, extensions and a menu
feedback.partly: Not quite correct. Adapt allows the following plugins: A theme, components, extensions and a menu
